action.action-desc: Mr. Nadler introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend title 18, United States Code, to place limitations on the possession, sale, and other disposition of a firearm by persons convicted of misdemeanor sex offenses against children.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Keep Kids Safe Act of 2013 .

section.header: Limits on possession, sale, and disposition of firearms by persons convicted of misdemeanor sex offenses against minors

subsection.text: Section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking or at the end of paragraph (8);
by inserting after paragraph (9) the following:
has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor sex offense against a minor.

subsection.text: Section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking or at the end of paragraph (8);
by striking the comma at the end of paragraph (9) and inserting ; or; and
by inserting after paragraph (9) the following:
who has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor sex offense against a minor,

subsection.header: Misdemeanor sex offense against a minor defined
subsection.text: Section 921(a) of such title is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: The term misdemeanor sex offense against a minor means a sex offense against a minor punishable by imprisonment for not more than one year.
The term sex offense means a criminal offense that has, as an element, a sexual act or sexual contact with another, or an attempt or conspiracy to commit such an offense.
The term minor means an individual who has not attained 18 years of age.
A person shall not be considered to have been convicted of a misdemeanor sex offense against a minor for purposes of this chapter—

subclause.text: the person was represented by counsel in the case, or knowingly and intelligently waived the right to counsel in the case; and
in the case of a prosecution for the offense for which a person was entitled to a jury trial in the jurisdiction in which the case was tried—

item.text: the case was tried by a jury; or

clause.text: if the conviction has been expunged or set aside, or is an offense for which the person has been pardoned or has had civil rights restored (if the law of the applicable jurisdiction provides for the loss of civil rights under such an offense), unless the pardon, expungement, or restoration of civil rights expressly provides that the person may not ship, transport, possess, or receive firearms.
